title.zh: 《孫子吳起列傳》 Biographies of Sun Tzu and Wu Qi
title.raw: 《孫子吳起列傳》 Biographies of Sun Tzu and Wu Qi

sentences.zh: 孫子武者，齊人也。

translations.literal: Sun Tzu Wu was a man from Qi.
translations.idiomatic: Sun Tzu Wu was a man from Qi.

sentences.zh: 以兵法見於吳王闔廬。

translations.literal: He presented himself to King Helü of Wu with his military strategies.
translations.idiomatic: He presented himself to King Helü of Wu with his military strategies.

sentences.zh: 闔廬曰：「子之十三篇，吾盡觀之矣，可以小試勒兵乎？」

translations.literal: Helü said: 'I have completely read your thirteen chapters. Could you conduct a small test of drilling troops?'
translations.idiomatic: Helü said: 'I have completely read your thirteen chapters. Could you conduct a small test of drilling troops?'

sentences.zh: 對曰：「可。」

translations.literal: He replied: 'Acceptable.'
translations.idiomatic: He replied: 'Acceptable.'

sentences.zh: 闔廬曰：「可試以婦人乎？」

translations.literal: Helü said: 'Could you test with women?'
translations.idiomatic: Helü said: 'Could you test with women?'

translations.literal: He said: 'Acceptable.'
translations.idiomatic: He said: 'Acceptable.'

sentences.zh: 於是許之，出宮中美女，得百八十人。

translations.literal: So he was permitted to do so. Palace ladies were selected, one hundred and eighty of them.
translations.idiomatic: So he was permitted to do so. Palace ladies were selected, one hundred and eighty of them.

sentences.zh: 孫子分為二隊，以王之寵姬二人各為隊長，皆令持戟。

translations.literal: Sun Tzu divided them into two teams, with the king's two favored consorts as team leaders for each, and commanded all of them to hold halberds.
translations.idiomatic: Sun Tzu divided them into two teams, with the king's two favored consorts as team leaders for each, and commanded all of them to hold halberds.

sentences.zh: 令之曰：「汝知而心與左右手背乎？」

translations.literal: He commanded them saying: 'Do you know your heart and your left right hand back?'
translations.idiomatic: He commanded them saying: 'Do you know your heart and your left right hand back?'

sentences.zh: 婦人曰：「知之。」

translations.literal: The women said: 'We know them.'
translations.idiomatic: The women said: 'We know them.'

sentences.zh: 孫子曰：「前，則視心；

translations.literal: Sun Tzu said: 'Forward, then look at the heart;
translations.idiomatic: Sun Tzu said: 'Forward, then look at the heart;

sentences.zh: 左，視左手；

translations.literal: left, look at the left hand;
translations.idiomatic: left, look at the left hand;

sentences.zh: 右，視右手；

translations.literal: right, look at the right hand;
translations.idiomatic: right, look at the right hand;

sentences.zh: 後，即視背。」

translations.literal: back, then look at the back.'
translations.idiomatic: back, then look at the back.'

sentences.zh: 婦人曰：「諾。」

translations.literal: The women said: 'Yes.'
translations.idiomatic: The women said: 'Yes.'

sentences.zh: 約束既布，乃設鈇鉞，即三令五申之。

translations.literal: Once the rules were laid out, he set up the axe and halberd, and repeated the commands three times and explained them five times.
translations.idiomatic: Once the rules were laid out, he set up the axe and halberd, and repeated the commands three times and explained them five times.

sentences.zh: 於是鼓之右，婦人大笑。

translations.literal: Then he drummed to the right, and the women burst out laughing.
translations.idiomatic: Then he drummed to the right, and the women burst out laughing.

sentences.zh: 孫子曰：「約束不明，申令不熟，將之罪也。」

translations.literal: Sun Tzu said: 'The rules are unclear, the commands are not familiar—the general's fault.'
translations.idiomatic: Sun Tzu said: 'The rules are unclear, the commands are not familiar—the general's fault.'

sentences.zh: 復三令五申而鼓之左，婦人復大笑。

translations.literal: He repeated the commands three times and explained them five times, then drummed to the left, and the women again burst out laughing.
translations.idiomatic: He repeated the commands three times and explained them five times, then drummed to the left, and the women again burst out laughing.

sentences.zh: 孫子曰：「約束不明，申令不熟，將之罪也；

translations.literal: Sun Tzu said: 'The rules are unclear, the commands are not familiar—the general's fault;
translations.idiomatic: Sun Tzu said: 'The rules are unclear, the commands are not familiar—the general's fault;

sentences.zh: 既已明而不如法者，吏士之罪也。」

translations.literal: once they are clear but not followed, it is the officers and soldiers' fault.'
translations.idiomatic: once they are clear but not followed, it is the officers and soldiers' fault.'

sentences.zh: 乃欲斬左右隊長。

translations.literal: He was about to execute the team leaders on left and right.
translations.idiomatic: He was about to execute the team leaders on left and right.

sentences.zh: 吳王從臺上觀，見且斬愛姬，大駭。

translations.literal: King Wu watched from the terrace above, and seeing that his beloved consorts were about to be executed, he was greatly alarmed.
translations.idiomatic: King Wu watched from the terrace above, and seeing that his beloved consorts were about to be executed, he was greatly alarmed.

sentences.zh: 趣使使下令曰：「寡人已知將軍能用兵矣。

translations.literal: He hurriedly sent a messenger down with orders: 'I already know the general can use troops.
translations.idiomatic: He hurriedly sent a messenger down with orders: 'I already know the general can use troops.

sentences.zh: 寡人非此二姬，食不甘味，願勿斬也。」

translations.literal: Without these two consorts, my food has no flavor. Please do not execute them.'
translations.idiomatic: Without these two consorts, my food has no flavor. Please do not execute them.'

sentences.zh: 孫子曰：「臣既已受命為將，將在軍，君命有所不受。」

translations.literal: Sun Tzu said: 'I have already received the command to be general; when in the army, the general does not accept the sovereign's orders.'
translations.idiomatic: Sun Tzu said: 'I have already received the command to be general; when in the army, the general does not accept the sovereign's orders.'

sentences.zh: 遂斬隊長二人以徇。

translations.literal: He executed the two team leaders as an example.
translations.idiomatic: He executed the two team leaders as an example.

sentences.zh: 用其次為隊長，於是復鼓之。

translations.literal: He appointed their seconds as team leaders, then drummed again.
translations.idiomatic: He appointed their seconds as team leaders, then drummed again.

sentences.zh: 婦人左右前後跪起皆中規矩繩墨，無敢出聲。

translations.literal: The women moved left right forward back, kneeling and standing—all conformed to the rules and regulations, none dared make a sound.
translations.idiomatic: The women moved left right forward back, kneeling and standing—all conformed to the rules and regulations, none dared make a sound.

sentences.zh: 於是孫子使使報王曰：「兵既整齊，王可試下觀之，唯王所欲用之，雖赴水火猶可也。」

translations.literal: Then Sun Tzu sent a messenger to report to the king: 'The troops are now well-ordered. Your Majesty can come down to observe them. Whatever you wish to use them for, even if it means charging into water or fire, they will do it.'
translations.idiomatic: Then Sun Tzu sent a messenger to report to the king: 'The troops are now well-ordered. Your Majesty can come down to observe them. Whatever you wish to use them for, even if it means charging into water or fire, they will do it.'

sentences.zh: 吳王曰：「將軍罷休就舍，寡人不願下觀。」

translations.literal: King Wu said: 'General, please retire to your quarters. I do not wish to come down and observe.'
translations.idiomatic: King Wu said: 'General, please retire to your quarters. I do not wish to come down and observe.'

sentences.zh: 孫子曰：「王徒好其言，不能用其實。」

translations.literal: Sun Tzu said: 'The king only likes the words but cannot use the reality.'
translations.idiomatic: Sun Tzu said: 'The king only likes the words but cannot use the reality.'

sentences.zh: 於是闔廬知孫子能用兵，卒以為將。

translations.literal: Thus Helü knew Sun Tzu could use troops and finally appointed him as general.
translations.idiomatic: Thus Helü knew Sun Tzu could use troops and finally appointed him as general.

sentences.zh: 西破彊楚，入郢，北威齊晉，顯名諸侯，孫子與有力焉。

translations.literal: He broke the strong state of Chu in the west, entered Ying, awed Qi and Jin in the north, made his name illustrious among the feudal lords—Sun Tzu had a role in this.
translations.idiomatic: He broke the strong state of Chu in the west, entered Ying, awed Qi and Jin in the north, made his name illustrious among the feudal lords—Sun Tzu had a role in this.

translations.literal: Sun Tzu Wu was a man from Qi. He presented himself to King Helü of Wu with his military strategies. Helü said: 'I have completely read your thirteen chapters. Could you conduct a small test of drilling troops?' He replied: 'Acceptable.' Helü said: 'Could you test with women?' He said: 'Acceptable.' So he was permitted to do so. Palace ladies were selected, one hundred and eighty of them. Sun Tzu divided them into two teams, with the king's two favored consorts as team leaders for each, and commanded all of them to hold halberds. He commanded them saying: 'Do you know your heart and your left right hand back?' The women said: 'We know them.' Sun Tzu said: 'Forward, then look at the heart; left, look at the left hand; right, look at the right hand; back, then look at the back.' The women said: 'Yes.' Once the rules were laid out, he set up the axe and halberd, and repeated the commands three times and explained them five times. Then he drummed to the right, and the women burst out laughing. Sun Tzu said: 'The rules are unclear, the commands are not familiar—the general's fault.' He repeated the commands three times and explained them five times, then drummed to the left, and the women again burst out laughing. Sun Tzu said: 'The rules are unclear, the commands are not familiar—the general's fault; once they are clear but not followed, it is the officers and soldiers' fault.' He was about to execute the team leaders on left and right. King Wu watched from the terrace above, and seeing that his beloved consorts were about to be executed, he was greatly alarmed. He hurriedly sent a messenger down with orders: 'I already know the general can use troops. Without these two consorts, my food has no flavor. Please do not execute them.' Sun Tzu said: 'I have already received the command to be general; when in the army, the general does not accept the sovereign's orders.' He executed the two team leaders as an example. He appointed their seconds as team leaders, then drummed again. The women moved left right forward back, kneeling and standing—all conformed to the rules and regulations, none dared make a sound. Then Sun Tzu sent a messenger to report to the king: 'The troops are now well-ordered. Your Majesty can come down to observe them. Whatever you wish to use them for, even if it means charging into water or fire, they will do it.' King Wu said: 'General, please retire to your quarters. I do not wish to come down and observe.' Sun Tzu said: 'The king only likes the words but cannot use the reality.' Thus Helü knew Sun Tzu could use troops and finally appointed him as general. He broke the strong state of Chu in the west, entered Ying, awed Qi and Jin in the north, made his name illustrious among the feudal lords—Sun Tzu had a role in this.

sentences.zh: 孫武既死，後百餘歲有孫臏。

translations.literal: After Sun Wu died, more than a century later there was Sun Bin.
translations.idiomatic: After Sun Wu died, more than a century later there was Sun Bin.

sentences.zh: 臏生阿鄄之閒，臏亦孫武之後世子孫也。

translations.literal: Bin was born between Ao and Juan. Bin was also a descendant of Sun Wu's lineage.
translations.idiomatic: Bin was born between Ao and Juan. Bin was also a descendant of Sun Wu's lineage.

sentences.zh: 孫臏嘗與龐涓俱學兵法。

translations.literal: Sun Bin once studied military strategy together with Pang Juan.
translations.idiomatic: Sun Bin once studied military strategy together with Pang Juan.

sentences.zh: 龐涓既事魏，得為惠王將軍，而自以為能不及孫臏，乃陰使召孫臏。

translations.literal: After Pang Juan served Wei, he became General to Marquis Hui, but felt his abilities did not match Sun Bin's, so he secretly summoned Sun Bin.
translations.idiomatic: After Pang Juan served Wei, he became General to Marquis Hui, but felt his abilities did not match Sun Bin's, so he secretly summoned Sun Bin.

sentences.zh: 臏至，龐涓恐其賢於己，疾之，則以法刑斷其兩足而黥之，欲隱勿見。

translations.literal: When Bin arrived, Pang Juan feared he was more worthy than himself, disliked him, and had his feet cut off and tattooed him to hide him away and not let him be seen.
translations.idiomatic: When Bin arrived, Pang Juan feared he was more worthy than himself, disliked him, and had his feet cut off and tattooed him to hide him away and not let him be seen.

translations.literal: After Sun Wu died, more than a century later there was Sun Bin. Bin was born between Ao and Juan. Bin was also a descendant of Sun Wu's lineage. Sun Bin once studied military strategy together with Pang Juan. After Pang Juan served Wei, he became General to Marquis Hui, but felt his abilities did not match Sun Bin's, so he secretly summoned Sun Bin. When Bin arrived, Pang Juan feared he was more worthy than himself, disliked him, and had his feet cut off and tattooed him to hide him away and not let him be seen.

sentences.zh: 齊使者如梁，孫臏以刑徒陰見，說齊使。

translations.literal: A Qi envoy came to Liang, and Sun Bin, as a criminal laborer, secretly met with him and persuaded him.
translations.idiomatic: A Qi envoy came to Liang, and Sun Bin, as a criminal laborer, secretly met with him and persuaded him.

sentences.zh: 齊使以為奇，竊載與之齊。

translations.literal: The Qi envoy considered him extraordinary and secretly carried him back to Qi.
translations.idiomatic: The Qi envoy considered him extraordinary and secretly carried him back to Qi.

sentences.zh: 齊將田忌善而客待之。

translations.literal: The Qi general Tian Ji treated him well as a guest.
translations.idiomatic: The Qi general Tian Ji treated him well as a guest.

sentences.zh: 忌數與齊諸公子馳逐重射。

translations.literal: Ji often raced chariots with the Qi nobles and wagered heavily.
translations.idiomatic: Ji often raced chariots with the Qi nobles and wagered heavily.

sentences.zh: 孫子見其馬足不甚相遠，馬有上、中、下、輩。

translations.literal: Sun Tzu saw that their horses' speeds were not far apart, with horses divided into upper, middle, lower, and lowest grades.
translations.idiomatic: Sun Tzu saw that their horses' speeds were not far apart, with horses divided into upper, middle, lower, and lowest grades.

sentences.zh: 於是孫子謂田忌曰：「君弟重射，臣能令君勝。」

translations.literal: So Sun Tzu said to Tian Ji: 'My lord wagers heavily in chariot races. I can make you win.'
translations.idiomatic: So Sun Tzu said to Tian Ji: 'My lord wagers heavily in chariot races. I can make you win.'

sentences.zh: 田忌信然之，與王及諸公子逐射千金。

translations.literal: Tian Ji believed him and wagered a thousand jin with the king and nobles.
translations.idiomatic: Tian Ji believed him and wagered a thousand jin with the king and nobles.

sentences.zh: 及臨質，孫子曰：「今以君之下駟與彼上駟，取君上駟與彼中駟，取君中駟與彼下駟。」

translations.literal: When it came time for the race, Sun Tzu said: 'Now use your lowest chariot against their highest, your highest against their middle, your middle against their lowest.'
translations.idiomatic: When it came time for the race, Sun Tzu said: 'Now use your lowest chariot against their highest, your highest against their middle, your middle against their lowest.'

sentences.zh: 既馳三輩畢，而田忌一不勝而再勝，卒得王千金。

translations.literal: After the three rounds were complete, Tian Ji lost one round but won two, and ultimately won the king's thousand jin.
translations.idiomatic: After the three rounds were complete, Tian Ji lost one round but won two, and ultimately won the king's thousand jin.

sentences.zh: 於是忌進孫子於威王。

translations.literal: So Ji recommended Sun Tzu to King Wei.
translations.idiomatic: So Ji recommended Sun Tzu to King Wei.

sentences.zh: 威王問兵法，遂以為師。

translations.literal: King Wei asked about military strategy and appointed him as teacher.
translations.idiomatic: King Wei asked about military strategy and appointed him as teacher.

translations.literal: A Qi envoy came to Liang, and Sun Bin, as a criminal laborer, secretly met with him and persuaded him. The Qi envoy considered him extraordinary and secretly carried him back to Qi. The Qi general Tian Ji treated him well as a guest. Ji often raced chariots with the Qi nobles and wagered heavily. Sun Tzu saw that their horses' speeds were not far apart, with horses divided into upper, middle, lower, and lowest grades. So Sun Tzu said to Tian Ji: 'My lord wagers heavily in chariot races. I can make you win.' Tian Ji believed him and wagered a thousand jin with the king and nobles. When it came time for the race, Sun Tzu said: 'Now use your lowest chariot against their highest, your highest against their middle, your middle against their lowest.' After the three rounds were complete, Tian Ji lost one round but won two, and ultimately won the king's thousand jin. So Ji recommended Sun Tzu to King Wei. King Wei asked about military strategy and appointed him as teacher.

sentences.zh: 其後魏伐趙，趙急，請救於齊。

translations.literal: Afterward, Wei attacked Zhao, Zhao was in dire straits and requested aid from Qi.
translations.idiomatic: Afterward, Wei attacked Zhao, Zhao was in dire straits and requested aid from Qi.

sentences.zh: 齊威王欲將孫臏，臏辭謝曰：「刑餘之人不可。」

translations.literal: King Wei of Qi wanted to appoint Sun Bin as general, but Bin declined saying: 'A mutilated criminal cannot.'
translations.idiomatic: King Wei of Qi wanted to appoint Sun Bin as general, but Bin declined saying: 'A mutilated criminal cannot.'

sentences.zh: 於是乃以田忌為將，而孫子為師，居輜車中，坐為計謀。

translations.literal: So they appointed Tian Ji as general and Sun Tzu as advisor, riding in the supply wagon, seated and making plans.
translations.idiomatic: So they appointed Tian Ji as general and Sun Tzu as advisor, riding in the supply wagon, seated and making plans.

sentences.zh: 田忌欲引兵之趙，孫子曰：「夫解雜亂紛糾者不控棬，救鬬者不搏撠，批亢擣虛，形格勢禁，則自為解耳。

translations.literal: Tian Ji wanted to lead troops to Zhao, but Sun Tzu said: 'Those who unravel tangles do not grab the fist, those who save fighters do not strike the head—strike the flanks and attack where empty, block their momentum and restrict their position, and they will resolve themselves.
translations.idiomatic: Tian Ji wanted to lead troops to Zhao, but Sun Tzu said: 'Those who unravel tangles do not grab the fist, those who save fighters do not strike the head—strike the flanks and attack where empty, block their momentum and restrict their position, and they will resolve themselves.

sentences.zh: 今梁趙相攻，輕兵銳卒必竭於外，老弱罷於內。

translations.literal: Now Liang and Zhao are attacking each other, their light troops and elite soldiers must be exhausted outside, the old and weak weary inside.
translations.idiomatic: Now Liang and Zhao are attacking each other, their light troops and elite soldiers must be exhausted outside, the old and weak weary inside.

sentences.zh: 君不若引兵疾走大梁，據其街路，衝其方虛，彼必釋趙而自救。

translations.literal: My lord should lead troops and swiftly march to Daliang, occupy their thoroughfares, strike their vulnerable points—they will surely abandon Zhao and come to their own rescue.
translations.idiomatic: My lord should lead troops and swiftly march to Daliang, occupy their thoroughfares, strike their vulnerable points—they will surely abandon Zhao and come to their own rescue.

sentences.zh: 是我一舉解趙之圍而收獘於魏也。」

translations.literal: This way we can lift Zhao's siege with one stroke and gain exhausted troops from Wei.'
translations.idiomatic: This way we can lift Zhao's siege with one stroke and gain exhausted troops from Wei.'

sentences.zh: 田忌從之，魏果去邯鄲，與齊戰於桂陵，大破梁軍。

translations.literal: Tian Ji followed this, and Wei indeed left Handan and fought Qi at Guiling, suffering a great defeat.
translations.idiomatic: Tian Ji followed this, and Wei indeed left Handan and fought Qi at Guiling, suffering a great defeat.

translations.literal: Afterward, Wei attacked Zhao, Zhao was in dire straits and requested aid from Qi. King Wei of Qi wanted to appoint Sun Bin as general, but Bin declined saying: 'A mutilated criminal cannot.' So they appointed Tian Ji as general and Sun Tzu as advisor, riding in the supply wagon, seated and making plans. Tian Ji wanted to lead troops to Zhao, but Sun Tzu said: 'Those who unravel tangles do not grab the fist, those who save fighters do not strike the head—strike the flanks and attack where empty, block their momentum and restrict their position, and they will resolve themselves. Now Liang and Zhao are attacking each other, their light troops and elite soldiers must be exhausted outside, the old and weak weary inside. My lord should lead troops and swiftly march to Daliang, occupy their thoroughfares, strike their vulnerable points—they will surely abandon Zhao and come to their own rescue. This way we can lift Zhao's siege with one stroke and gain exhausted troops from Wei.' Tian Ji followed this, and Wei indeed left Handan and fought Qi at Guiling, suffering a great defeat.

sentences.zh: 後十三歲，魏與趙攻韓，韓告急於齊。

translations.literal: Thirteen years later, Wei and Zhao attacked Han, Han urgently appealed to Qi.
translations.idiomatic: Thirteen years later, Wei and Zhao attacked Han, Han urgently appealed to Qi.

sentences.zh: 齊使田忌將而往，直走大梁。

translations.literal: Qi sent Tian Ji as general to go, directly marching to Daliang.
translations.idiomatic: Qi sent Tian Ji as general to go, directly marching to Daliang.

sentences.zh: 魏將龐涓聞之，去韓而歸，齊軍既已過而西矣。

translations.literal: Wei general Pang Juan heard of it, left Han and returned, but the Qi army had already passed and gone west.
translations.idiomatic: Wei general Pang Juan heard of it, left Han and returned, but the Qi army had already passed and gone west.

sentences.zh: 孫子謂田忌曰：「彼三晉之兵素悍勇而輕齊，齊號為怯，善戰者因其勢而利導之。

translations.literal: Sun Tzu said to Tian Ji: 'The troops of the three Jin states are fierce and brave by nature and look down on Qi. Qi has a reputation for cowardice. Good warriors exploit their momentum and guide it advantageously.
translations.idiomatic: Sun Tzu said to Tian Ji: 'The troops of the three Jin states are fierce and brave by nature and look down on Qi. Qi has a reputation for cowardice. Good warriors exploit their momentum and guide it advantageously.

sentences.zh: 兵法，百里而趣利者蹶上將，五十里而趣利者軍半至。

translations.literal: Military strategy says: those who pursue advantage a hundred li lose their general, those who pursue advantage fifty li arrive with half their army.
translations.idiomatic: Military strategy says: those who pursue advantage a hundred li lose their general, those who pursue advantage fifty li arrive with half their army.

sentences.zh: 使齊軍入魏地為十萬灶，明日為五萬灶，又明日為三萬灶。」

translations.literal: Have the Qi army enter Wei territory and make ten thousand cooking fires, the next day five thousand, the day after three thousand.'
translations.idiomatic: Have the Qi army enter Wei territory and make ten thousand cooking fires, the next day five thousand, the day after three thousand.'

sentences.zh: 龐涓行三日，大喜，曰：「我固知齊軍怯，入吾地三日，士卒亡者過半矣。」

translations.literal: Pang Juan marched three days and was greatly pleased, saying: 'I knew the Qi army was cowardly. Entering our territory three days, more than half their soldiers have deserted.'
translations.idiomatic: Pang Juan marched three days and was greatly pleased, saying: 'I knew the Qi army was cowardly. Entering our territory three days, more than half their soldiers have deserted.'

sentences.zh: 乃棄其步軍，與其輕銳倍日并行逐之。

translations.literal: He abandoned his infantry and with his light elite doubled their march to pursue them.
translations.idiomatic: He abandoned his infantry and with his light elite doubled their march to pursue them.

sentences.zh: 孫子度其行，暮當至馬陵。

translations.literal: Sun Tzu calculated their march route—they should arrive at Malings by dusk.
translations.idiomatic: Sun Tzu calculated their march route—they should arrive at Malings by dusk.

sentences.zh: 馬陵道陜，而旁多阻隘，可伏兵，乃斫大樹白而書之曰「龐涓死于此樹之下」。

translations.literal: The Malings road was narrow, with many obstacles and defiles on the sides, suitable for ambushing troops. They cut a large tree white and wrote on it: 'Pang Juan dies beneath this tree.'
translations.idiomatic: The Malings road was narrow, with many obstacles and defiles on the sides, suitable for ambushing troops. They cut a large tree white and wrote on it: 'Pang Juan dies beneath this tree.'

sentences.zh: 於是令齊軍善射者萬弩，夾道而伏，期曰「暮見火舉而俱發」。

translations.literal: Then they ordered the Qi army's best archers with ten thousand crossbows to lie in ambush along the road, setting a time: 'When you see fire at dusk, all fire together.'
translations.idiomatic: Then they ordered the Qi army's best archers with ten thousand crossbows to lie in ambush along the road, setting a time: 'When you see fire at dusk, all fire together.'

sentences.zh: 龐涓果夜至斫木下，見白書，乃鉆火燭之。

translations.literal: Pang Juan indeed arrived at night beneath the cut tree, saw the white writing, and lit a torch to read it.
translations.idiomatic: Pang Juan indeed arrived at night beneath the cut tree, saw the white writing, and lit a torch to read it.

sentences.zh: 讀其書未畢，齊軍萬弩俱發，魏軍大亂相失。

translations.literal: He had not finished reading the writing when the Qi army's ten thousand crossbows all fired, and the Wei army fell into great chaos and scattered.
translations.idiomatic: He had not finished reading the writing when the Qi army's ten thousand crossbows all fired, and the Wei army fell into great chaos and scattered.

sentences.zh: 龐涓自知智窮兵敗，乃自剄，曰：「遂成豎子之名！」

translations.literal: Pang Juan knew his wisdom was exhausted and his troops defeated, so he cut his own throat, saying: 'This fulfills the reputation of that boy!'
translations.idiomatic: Pang Juan knew his wisdom was exhausted and his troops defeated, so he cut his own throat, saying: 'This fulfills the reputation of that boy!'

sentences.zh: 齊因乘勝盡破其軍，虜魏太子申以歸。

translations.literal: Qi took advantage of the victory to completely destroy their army, capturing Wei's crown prince Shen and returning.
translations.idiomatic: Qi took advantage of the victory to completely destroy their army, capturing Wei's crown prince Shen and returning.

sentences.zh: 孫臏以此名顯天下，世傳其兵法。

translations.literal: Sun Bin thereby became famous throughout the world, and his military strategy was transmitted through the ages.
translations.idiomatic: Sun Bin thereby became famous throughout the world, and his military strategy was transmitted through the ages.

translations.literal: Thirteen years later, Wei and Zhao attacked Han, Han urgently appealed to Qi. Qi sent Tian Ji as general to go, directly marching to Daliang. Wei general Pang Juan heard of it, left Han and returned, but the Qi army had already passed and gone west. Sun Tzu said to Tian Ji: 'The troops of the three Jin states are fierce and brave by nature and look down on Qi. Qi has a reputation for cowardice. Good warriors exploit their momentum and guide it advantageously. Military strategy says: those who pursue advantage a hundred li lose their general, those who pursue advantage fifty li arrive with half their army. Have the Qi army enter Wei territory and make ten thousand cooking fires, the next day five thousand, the day after three thousand.' Pang Juan marched three days and was greatly pleased, saying: 'I knew the Qi army was cowardly. Entering our territory three days, more than half their soldiers have deserted.' He abandoned his infantry and with his light elite doubled their march to pursue them. Sun Tzu calculated their march route—they should arrive at Malings by dusk. The Malings road was narrow, with many obstacles and defiles on the sides, suitable for ambushing troops. They cut a large tree white and wrote on it: 'Pang Juan dies beneath this tree.' Then they ordered the Qi army's best archers with ten thousand crossbows to lie in ambush along the road, setting a time: 'When you see fire at dusk, all fire together.' Pang Juan indeed arrived at night beneath the cut tree, saw the white writing, and lit a torch to read it. He had not finished reading the writing when the Qi army's ten thousand crossbows all fired, and the Wei army fell into great chaos and scattered. Pang Juan knew his wisdom was exhausted and his troops defeated, so he cut his own throat, saying: 'This fulfills the reputation of that boy!' Qi took advantage of the victory to completely destroy their army, capturing Wei's crown prince Shen and returning. Sun Bin thereby became famous throughout the world, and his military strategy was transmitted through the ages.

sentences.zh: 吳起者，衛人也，好用兵。

translations.literal: Wu Qi was a man from Wei.
translations.idiomatic: Wu Qi was a man from Wei.

sentences.zh: 嘗學於曾子，事魯君。

translations.literal: He once studied under Zengzi and served the Lord of Lu.
translations.idiomatic: He once studied under Zengzi and served the Lord of Lu.

sentences.zh: 齊人攻魯，魯欲將吳起，吳起取齊女為妻，而魯疑之。

translations.literal: When Qi attacked Lu, Lu wanted to appoint Wu Qi as general, but Wu Qi had taken a Qi woman as wife, so Lu suspected him.
translations.idiomatic: When Qi attacked Lu, Lu wanted to appoint Wu Qi as general, but Wu Qi had taken a Qi woman as wife, so Lu suspected him.

sentences.zh: 吳起於是欲就名，遂殺其妻，以明不與齊也。

translations.literal: Wu Qi then wanted to establish his reputation, so he killed his wife to show he had no connection with Qi.
translations.idiomatic: Wu Qi then wanted to establish his reputation, so he killed his wife to show he had no connection with Qi.

sentences.zh: 魯卒以為將。

translations.literal: Lu finally appointed him as general.
translations.idiomatic: Lu finally appointed him as general.

sentences.zh: 將而攻齊，大破之。

translations.literal: As general he attacked Qi and greatly defeated them.
translations.idiomatic: As general he attacked Qi and greatly defeated them.

translations.literal: Wu Qi was a man from Wei. He once studied under Zengzi and served the Lord of Lu. When Qi attacked Lu, Lu wanted to appoint Wu Qi as general, but Wu Qi had taken a Qi woman as wife, so Lu suspected him. Wu Qi then wanted to establish his reputation, so he killed his wife to show he had no connection with Qi. Lu finally appointed him as general. As general he attacked Qi and greatly defeated them.

sentences.zh: 魯人或惡吳起曰：「起之為人，猜忍人也。

translations.literal: Some Lu people spoke ill of Wu Qi saying: 'Qi is a suspicious and cruel person.
translations.idiomatic: Some Lu people spoke ill of Wu Qi saying: 'Qi is a suspicious and cruel person.

sentences.zh: 其少時，家累千金，游仕不遂，遂破其家，鄉黨笑之，吳起殺其謗己者三十餘人，而東出衛郭門。

translations.literal: In his youth, his family had accumulated a thousand jin. He sought office but did not succeed, so he squandered his family fortune. The villagers laughed at him. Wu Qi killed more than thirty of those who slandered him and left east through the Wei city gate.
translations.idiomatic: In his youth, his family had accumulated a thousand jin. He sought office but did not succeed, so he squandered his family fortune. The villagers laughed at him. Wu Qi killed more than thirty of those who slandered him and left east through the Wei city gate.

sentences.zh: 與其母訣，齧臂而盟曰：『起不為卿相，不復入衛。』

translations.literal: He bid farewell to his mother, bit his arm and swore: 'If I do not become prime minister, I will not return to Wei.'
translations.idiomatic: He bid farewell to his mother, bit his arm and swore: 'If I do not become prime minister, I will not return to Wei.'

sentences.zh: 遂事曾子。

translations.literal: So he served Zengzi.
translations.idiomatic: So he served Zengzi.

sentences.zh: 居頃之，其母死，起終不歸。

translations.literal: After some time, his mother died, but Qi did not return.
translations.idiomatic: After some time, his mother died, but Qi did not return.

sentences.zh: 曾子薄之，而與起絕。

translations.literal: Zengzi despised him and broke relations with him.
translations.idiomatic: Zengzi despised him and broke relations with him.

sentences.zh: 起乃之魯，學兵法以事魯君。

translations.literal: Qi then went to Lu and studied military strategy to serve the Lord of Lu.
translations.idiomatic: Qi then went to Lu and studied military strategy to serve the Lord of Lu.

sentences.zh: 魯君疑之，起殺妻以求將。

translations.literal: The Lord of Lu suspected him, so Qi killed his wife to seek the generalship.
translations.idiomatic: The Lord of Lu suspected him, so Qi killed his wife to seek the generalship.

sentences.zh: 夫魯小國，而有戰勝之名，則諸侯圖魯矣。

translations.literal: Lu is a small state, and if it has the name of victory in battle, the feudal lords will covet Lu.
translations.idiomatic: Lu is a small state, and if it has the name of victory in battle, the feudal lords will covet Lu.

sentences.zh: 且魯衛兄弟之國也，而君用起，則是棄衛。」

translations.literal: Moreover, Lu and Wei are brother states, yet the lord employs Qi, which means abandoning Wei.'
translations.idiomatic: Moreover, Lu and Wei are brother states, yet the lord employs Qi, which means abandoning Wei.'

sentences.zh: 魯君疑之，謝吳起。

translations.literal: The Lord of Lu suspected him and dismissed Wu Qi.
translations.idiomatic: The Lord of Lu suspected him and dismissed Wu Qi.

translations.literal: Some Lu people spoke ill of Wu Qi saying: 'Qi is a suspicious and cruel person. In his youth, his family had accumulated a thousand jin. He sought office but did not succeed, so he squandered his family fortune. The villagers laughed at him. Wu Qi killed more than thirty of those who slandered him and left east through the Wei city gate. He bid farewell to his mother, bit his arm and swore: 'If I do not become prime minister, I will not return to Wei.' So he served Zengzi. After some time, his mother died, but Qi did not return. Zengzi despised him and broke relations with him. Qi then went to Lu and studied military strategy to serve the Lord of Lu. The Lord of Lu suspected him, so Qi killed his wife to seek the generalship. Lu is a small state, and if it has the name of victory in battle, the feudal lords will covet Lu. Moreover, Lu and Wei are brother states, yet the lord employs Qi, which means abandoning Wei.' The Lord of Lu suspected him and dismissed Wu Qi.

sentences.zh: 吳起於是聞魏文侯賢，欲事之。

translations.literal: Wu Qi then heard that Marquis Wen of Wei was worthy and wanted to serve him.
translations.idiomatic: Wu Qi then heard that Marquis Wen of Wei was worthy and wanted to serve him.

sentences.zh: 文侯問李克曰：「吳起何如人哉？」

translations.literal: Marquis Wen asked Li Ke: 'What kind of person is Wu Qi?'
translations.idiomatic: Marquis Wen asked Li Ke: 'What kind of person is Wu Qi?'

sentences.zh: 李克曰：「起貪而好色，然用兵司馬穰苴不能過也。」

translations.literal: Li Ke said: 'Qi is greedy and fond of women, but in using troops, even Sima Rangju cannot surpass him.'
translations.idiomatic: Li Ke said: 'Qi is greedy and fond of women, but in using troops, even Sima Rangju cannot surpass him.'

sentences.zh: 於是魏文候以為將，擊秦，拔五城。

translations.literal: So Marquis Wen of Wei appointed him as general and attacked Qin, capturing five cities.
translations.idiomatic: So Marquis Wen of Wei appointed him as general and attacked Qin, capturing five cities.

translations.literal: Wu Qi then heard that Marquis Wen of Wei was worthy and wanted to serve him. Marquis Wen asked Li Ke: 'What kind of person is Wu Qi?' Li Ke said: 'Qi is greedy and fond of women, but in using troops, even Sima Rangju cannot surpass him.' So Marquis Wen of Wei appointed him as general and attacked Qin, capturing five cities.

sentences.zh: 起之為將，與士卒最下者同衣食。

translations.literal: When Qi was general, he shared clothing and food with the lowest soldiers.
translations.idiomatic: When Qi was general, he shared clothing and food with the lowest soldiers.

sentences.zh: 臥不設席，行不騎乘，親裹贏糧，與士卒分勞苦。

translations.literal: He did not lay out mats when sleeping, did not ride when marching, personally wrapped the provisions, sharing hardship with the soldiers.
translations.idiomatic: He did not lay out mats when sleeping, did not ride when marching, personally wrapped the provisions, sharing hardship with the soldiers.

sentences.zh: 卒有病疽者，起為吮之。

translations.literal: When a soldier had a festering sore, Qi sucked it for him.
translations.idiomatic: When a soldier had a festering sore, Qi sucked it for him.

sentences.zh: 卒母聞而哭之。

translations.literal: The soldier's mother heard and wept for him.
translations.idiomatic: The soldier's mother heard and wept for him.

sentences.zh: 人曰：「子卒也，而將軍自吮其疽，何哭為？」

translations.literal: Someone said: 'Your son is a soldier, and the general himself sucked his sore. Why do you weep?'
translations.idiomatic: Someone said: 'Your son is a soldier, and the general himself sucked his sore. Why do you weep?'

sentences.zh: 母曰：「非然也。

translations.literal: The mother said: 'It's not that.
translations.idiomatic: The mother said: 'It's not that.

sentences.zh: 往年吳公吮其父，其父戰不旋踵，遂死於敵。

translations.literal: In previous years Lord Wu sucked my husband's sore, and my husband fought without turning back and died on the battlefield.
translations.idiomatic: In previous years Lord Wu sucked my husband's sore, and my husband fought without turning back and died on the battlefield.

sentences.zh: 吳公今又吮其子，妾不知其死所矣。

translations.literal: Now Lord Wu sucks my son's sore again. I don't know where my son will die.'
translations.idiomatic: Now Lord Wu sucks my son's sore again. I don't know where my son will die.'

sentences.zh: 是以哭之。」

translations.literal: So she wept for him.'
translations.idiomatic: So she wept for him.'

translations.literal: When Qi was general, he shared clothing and food with the lowest soldiers. He did not lay out mats when sleeping, did not ride when marching, personally wrapped the provisions, sharing hardship with the soldiers. When a soldier had a festering sore, Qi sucked it for him. The soldier's mother heard and wept for him. Someone said: 'Your son is a soldier, and the general himself sucked his sore. Why do you weep?' The mother said: 'It's not that. In previous years Lord Wu sucked my husband's sore, and my husband fought without turning back and died on the battlefield. Now Lord Wu sucks my son's sore again. I don't know where my son will die.' So she wept for him.'

sentences.zh: 文侯以吳起善用兵，廉平，盡能得士心，乃以為西河守，以拒秦、韓。

translations.literal: Marquis Wen considered Wu Qi skilled in using troops, incorruptible and fair, able to completely win the soldiers' hearts, so he appointed him governor of Xhe to resist Qin and Han.
translations.idiomatic: Marquis Wen considered Wu Qi skilled in using troops, incorruptible and fair, able to completely win the soldiers' hearts, so he appointed him governor of Xhe to resist Qin and Han.

translations.literal: Marquis Wen considered Wu Qi skilled in using troops, incorruptible and fair, able to completely win the soldiers' hearts, so he appointed him governor of Xhe to resist Qin and Han.

sentences.zh: 魏文侯既卒，起事其子武侯。

translations.literal: After Marquis Wen of Wei died, Qi served his son Marquis Wu.
translations.idiomatic: After Marquis Wen of Wei died, Qi served his son Marquis Wu.

sentences.zh: 武侯浮西河而下，中流，顧而謂吳起曰：「美哉乎山河之固，此魏國之寶也！」

translations.literal: Marquis Wu floated down the Yellow River, and in midstream turned to say to Wu Qi: 'How beautiful are the mountain and river fortifications—this is Wei's treasure!'
translations.idiomatic: Marquis Wu floated down the Yellow River, and in midstream turned to say to Wu Qi: 'How beautiful are the mountain and river fortifications—this is Wei's treasure!'

sentences.zh: 起對曰：「在德不在險。

translations.literal: Qi replied: 'It depends on virtue, not on natural defenses.
translations.idiomatic: Qi replied: 'It depends on virtue, not on natural defenses.

sentences.zh: 昔三苗氏左洞庭，右彭蠡，德義不修，禹滅之。

translations.literal: In ancient times the Three Miao tribes had Dongting on the left and Pengli on the right. They did not cultivate virtue and righteousness, so Yu destroyed them.
translations.idiomatic: In ancient times the Three Miao tribes had Dongting on the left and Pengli on the right. They did not cultivate virtue and righteousness, so Yu destroyed them.

sentences.zh: 夏桀之居，左河濟，右泰華，伊闕在其南，羊腸在其北，修政不仁，湯放之。

translations.literal: Xia Jie resided with the Yellow River on the left and Mount Tai on the right, Yique to the south and Yangchang to the north. He practiced unbenevolent government, so Tang exiled him.
translations.idiomatic: Xia Jie resided with the Yellow River on the left and Mount Tai on the right, Yique to the south and Yangchang to the north. He practiced unbenevolent government, so Tang exiled him.

sentences.zh: 殷紂之國，左孟門，右太行，常山在其北，大河經其南，修政不德，武王殺之。

translations.literal: King Zhou of Yin had Mengmen on the left and Taihang on the right, Changshan to the north and the great river flowing south. He practiced unde virtuous government, so King Wu killed him.
translations.idiomatic: King Zhou of Yin had Mengmen on the left and Taihang on the right, Changshan to the north and the great river flowing south. He practiced unde virtuous government, so King Wu killed him.

sentences.zh: 由此觀之，在德不在險。

translations.literal: From this we can see it depends on virtue, not on natural defenses.
translations.idiomatic: From this we can see it depends on virtue, not on natural defenses.

sentences.zh: 若君不修德，舟中之人盡為敵國也。」

translations.literal: If my lord does not cultivate virtue, everyone in this boat will become the enemy state's people.'
translations.idiomatic: If my lord does not cultivate virtue, everyone in this boat will become the enemy state's people.'

sentences.zh: 武侯曰：「善。」

translations.literal: Marquis Wu said: 'Excellent.'
translations.idiomatic: Marquis Wu said: 'Excellent.'

translations.literal: After Marquis Wen of Wei died, Qi served his son Marquis Wu. Marquis Wu floated down the Yellow River, and in midstream turned to say to Wu Qi: 'How beautiful are the mountain and river fortifications—this is Wei's treasure!' Qi replied: 'It depends on virtue, not on natural defenses. In ancient times the Three Miao tribes had Dongting on the left and Pengli on the right. They did not cultivate virtue and righteousness, so Yu destroyed them. Xia Jie resided with the Yellow River on the left and Mount Tai on the right, Yique to the south and Yangchang to the north. He practiced unbenevolent government, so Tang exiled him. King Zhou of Yin had Mengmen on the left and Taihang on the right, Changshan to the north and the great river flowing south. He practiced unde virtuous government, so King Wu killed him. From this we can see it depends on virtue, not on natural defenses. If my lord does not cultivate virtue, everyone in this boat will become the enemy state's people.' Marquis Wu said: 'Excellent.'

sentences.zh: （即封）吳起為西河守，甚有聲名。

translations.literal: He appointed Wu Qi as governor of Xhe, and he had great renown.
translations.idiomatic: He appointed Wu Qi as governor of Xhe, and he had great renown.

sentences.zh: 魏置相，相田文。

translations.literal: Wei appointed a chancellor, Chancellor Tian Wen.
translations.idiomatic: Wei appointed a chancellor, Chancellor Tian Wen.

sentences.zh: 吳起不悅，謂田文曰：「請與子論功，可乎？」

translations.literal: Wu Qi was displeased and said to Tian Wen: 'May I discuss merits with you?'
translations.idiomatic: Wu Qi was displeased and said to Tian Wen: 'May I discuss merits with you?'

sentences.zh: 田文曰：「可。」

translations.literal: Tian Wen said: 'Acceptable.'
translations.idiomatic: Tian Wen said: 'Acceptable.'

sentences.zh: 起曰：「將三軍，使士卒樂死，敵國不敢謀，子孰與起？」

translations.literal: Qi said: 'Commanding the three armies, making soldiers gladly die for you, enemy states not daring to plot—who compares to me?'
translations.idiomatic: Qi said: 'Commanding the three armies, making soldiers gladly die for you, enemy states not daring to plot—who compares to me?'

sentences.zh: 文曰：「不如子。」

translations.literal: Wen said: 'I do not match you.'
translations.idiomatic: Wen said: 'I do not match you.'

sentences.zh: 起曰：「治百官，親萬民，實府庫，子孰與起？」

translations.literal: Qi said: 'Managing the hundred officials, being close to the ten thousand people, filling the treasuries—who compares to me?'
translations.idiomatic: Qi said: 'Managing the hundred officials, being close to the ten thousand people, filling the treasuries—who compares to me?'

sentences.zh: 文曰：「不如子。」

translations.literal: Wen said: 'I do not match you.'
translations.idiomatic: Wen said: 'I do not match you.'

sentences.zh: 起曰：「守西河而秦兵不敢東鄉，韓趙賓從，子孰與起？」

translations.literal: Qi said: 'Guarding Xhe so Qin troops dare not face east, making Han and Zhao submit as guests—who compares to me?'
translations.idiomatic: Qi said: 'Guarding Xhe so Qin troops dare not face east, making Han and Zhao submit as guests—who compares to me?'

sentences.zh: 文曰：「不如子。」

translations.literal: Wen said: 'I do not match you.'
translations.idiomatic: Wen said: 'I do not match you.'

sentences.zh: 起曰：「此三者，子皆出吾下，而位加吾上，何也？」

translations.literal: Qi said: 'In these three matters you are all below me, yet your position is above mine. Why?'
translations.idiomatic: Qi said: 'In these three matters you are all below me, yet your position is above mine. Why?'

sentences.zh: 文曰：「主少國疑，大臣未附，百姓不信，方是之時，屬之於子乎？

translations.literal: Wen said: 'The lord is young, the state uncertain, ministers not yet attached, the people not yet trusting—at such a time, should it be entrusted to you or to me?'
translations.idiomatic: Wen said: 'The lord is young, the state uncertain, ministers not yet attached, the people not yet trusting—at such a time, should it be entrusted to you or to me?'

sentences.zh: 屬之於我乎？」

translations.literal: Qi was silent for a long time, then said: 'It should be entrusted to you.'
translations.idiomatic: Qi was silent for a long time, then said: 'It should be entrusted to you.'

sentences.zh: 起默然良久，曰：「屬之子矣。」

translations.literal: Wen said: 'This is why I am above you.'
translations.idiomatic: Wen said: 'This is why I am above you.'

sentences.zh: 文曰：「此乃吾所以居子之上也。」

translations.literal: Wu Qi then realized he was not equal to Tian Wen.
translations.idiomatic: Wu Qi then realized he was not equal to Tian Wen.

sentences.zh: 吳起乃自知弗如田文。

translations.literal: Wu Qi then realized he was not equal to Tian Wen.
translations.idiomatic: Wu Qi then realized he was not equal to Tian Wen.

translations.literal: He appointed Wu Qi as governor of Xhe, and he had great renown. Wei appointed a chancellor, Chancellor Tian Wen. Wu Qi was displeased and said to Tian Wen: 'May I discuss merits with you?' Tian Wen said: 'Acceptable.' Qi said: 'Commanding the three armies, making soldiers gladly die for you, enemy states not daring to plot—who compares to me?' Wen said: 'I do not match you.' Qi said: 'Guarding Xhe so Qin troops dare not face east, making Han and Zhao submit as guests—who compares to me?' Wen said: 'I do not match you.' After Tian Wen died, Gongsun became chancellor. He married the Wei princess but harmed Wu Qi.

sentences.zh: 田文既死，公叔為相，尚魏公主，而害吳起。

translations.literal: Gongsun's servant said: 'Qi can be easily removed.'
translations.idiomatic: Gongsun's servant said: 'Qi can be easily removed.'

sentences.zh: 公叔之仆曰：「起易去也。」

translations.literal: Gongsun's servant said: 'Qi can be easily removed.'
translations.idiomatic: Gongsun's servant said: 'Qi can be easily removed.'

sentences.zh: 公叔曰：「柰何？」

translations.literal: His servant said: 'Qi is frugal and self-satisfied with his reputation.
translations.idiomatic: His servant said: 'Qi is frugal and self-satisfied with his reputation.

sentences.zh: 其仆曰：「吳起為人節廉而自喜名也。

translations.literal: My lord should first speak to Marquis Wu: 'Wu Qi is a worthy person, but your lordship's state is small and borders strong Qin. I privately fear Qi may not be wholeheartedly devoted.'
translations.idiomatic: My lord should first speak to Marquis Wu: 'Wu Qi is a worthy person, but your lordship's state is small and borders strong Qin. I privately fear Qi may not be wholeheartedly devoted.'

sentences.zh: 君因先與武侯言曰：『夫吳起賢人也，而侯之國小，又與彊秦壤界，臣竊恐起之無留心也。』

translations.literal: My lord should first speak to Marquis Wu: 'Wu Qi is a worthy person, but your lordship's state is small and borders strong Qin. I privately fear Qi may not be wholeheartedly devoted.'
translations.idiomatic: My lord should first speak to Marquis Wu: 'Wu Qi is a worthy person, but your lordship's state is small and borders strong Qin. I privately fear Qi may not be wholeheartedly devoted.'

sentences.zh: 武侯即曰：『柰何？』

translations.literal: Marquis Wu will say: 'What then?'
translations.idiomatic: Marquis Wu will say: 'What then?'

sentences.zh: 君因謂武侯曰：『試延以公主，起有留心則必受之。

translations.literal: If he has no devotion he will certainly decline.
translations.idiomatic: If he has no devotion he will certainly decline.

sentences.zh: 無留心則必辭矣。

translations.literal: Use this to divine it.'
translations.idiomatic: Use this to divine it.'

sentences.zh: 以此卜之。』

translations.literal: Use this to divine it.'
translations.idiomatic: Use this to divine it.'

sentences.zh: 君因召吳起而與歸，即令公主怒而輕君。

translations.literal: When Wu Qi sees the princess insulting the Wei chancellor, he will certainly decline.'
translations.idiomatic: When Wu Qi sees the princess insulting the Wei chancellor, he will certainly decline.'

sentences.zh: 吳起見公主之賤君也，則必辭。」

translations.literal: So Wu Qi saw the princess insulting the Wei chancellor and indeed declined Marquis Wu.
translations.idiomatic: So Wu Qi saw the princess insulting the Wei chancellor and indeed declined Marquis Wu.

sentences.zh: 於是吳起見公主之賤魏相，果辭魏武侯。

translations.literal: Marquis Wu suspected it but did not believe.
translations.idiomatic: Marquis Wu suspected it but did not believe.

sentences.zh: 武侯疑之而弗信也。

translations.literal: Wu Qi feared punishment, so he left and went to Chu.
translations.idiomatic: Wu Qi feared punishment, so he left and went to Chu.

sentences.zh: 吳起懼得罪，遂去，即之楚。

translations.literal: King Dao of Chu had long heard Qi was worthy, and upon his arrival appointed him chancellor of Chu.
translations.idiomatic: King Dao of Chu had long heard Qi was worthy, and upon his arrival appointed him chancellor of Chu.

translations.literal: Gongsun's servant said: 'Qi can be easily removed.' Gongsun said: 'How?' His servant said: 'Qi is frugal and self-satisfied with his reputation. My lord should first speak to Marquis Wu: 'Wu Qi is a worthy person, but your lordship's state is small and borders strong Qin. I privately fear Qi may not be wholeheartedly devoted.' Marquis Wu will say: 'What then?' My lord then says to Marquis Wu: 'Test him by betrothing him the princess. If he has devotion he will certainly accept. If he has no devotion he will certainly decline. Use this to divine it.' My lord then summons Wu Qi and betroths him the princess, immediately making the princess angry and insulting my lord. When Wu Qi sees the princess insulting the Wei chancellor, he will certainly decline.' So Wu Qi saw the princess insulting the Wei chancellor and indeed declined Marquis Wu. Marquis Wu suspected it but did not believe. Wu Qi feared punishment, so he left and went to Chu. King Dao of Chu had long heard Qi was worthy, and upon his arrival appointed him chancellor of Chu.

sentences.zh: 楚悼王素聞起賢，至則相楚。

translations.literal: He clarified the laws and examined the commands, abolished unnecessary officials, dismissed distant royal clansmen, to nurture and fight with the soldiers.
translations.idiomatic: He clarified the laws and examined the commands, abolished unnecessary officials, dismissed distant royal clansmen, to nurture and fight with the soldiers.

sentences.zh: 明法審令，捐不急之官，廢公族疏遠者，以撫養戰鬬之士。

translations.literal: He emphasized strengthening the troops, rejecting the words of the strategists who spoke of alliances and confederacies.
translations.idiomatic: He emphasized strengthening the troops, rejecting the words of the strategists who spoke of alliances and confederacies.

sentences.zh: 要在彊兵，破馳說之言從橫者。

translations.literal: Thus he pacified Baiyue in the south;
translations.idiomatic: Thus he pacified Baiyue in the south;

sentences.zh: 於是南平百越；

translations.literal: annexed Chen and Cai in the north, drove back the three Jin;
translations.idiomatic: annexed Chen and Cai in the north, drove back the three Jin;

sentences.zh: 北并陳蔡，卻三晉；

translations.literal: attacked Qin in the west.
translations.idiomatic: attacked Qin in the west.

sentences.zh: 西伐秦。

translations.literal: The feudal lords feared Chu's strength.
translations.idiomatic: The feudal lords feared Chu's strength.

sentences.zh: 諸侯患楚之彊。

translations.literal: Therefore Chu's nobles all wanted to harm Wu Qi.
translations.idiomatic: Therefore Chu's nobles all wanted to harm Wu Qi.

sentences.zh: 故楚之貴戚盡欲害吳起。

translations.literal: Therefore Chu's nobles all wanted to harm Wu Qi.
translations.idiomatic: Therefore Chu's nobles all wanted to harm Wu Qi.

sentences.zh: 及悼王死，宗室大臣作亂而攻吳起，吳起走之王尸而伏之。

translations.literal: Those attacking Qi then shot and stabbed Wu Qi, also hitting King Dao.
translations.idiomatic: Those attacking Qi then shot and stabbed Wu Qi, also hitting King Dao.

sentences.zh: 擊起之徒因射刺吳起，并中悼王。

translations.literal: After King Dao was buried, the crown prince ascended and had the chief minister execute all those who shot Wu Qi and hit the king's corpse.
translations.idiomatic: After King Dao was buried, the crown prince ascended and had the chief minister execute all those who shot Wu Qi and hit the king's corpse.

sentences.zh: 悼王既葬，太子立，乃使令尹盡誅射吳起而并中王尸者。

translations.literal: Those executed for shooting Qi and whose clans were exterminated numbered more than seventy families.
translations.idiomatic: Those executed for shooting Qi and whose clans were exterminated numbered more than seventy families.

sentences.zh: 坐射起而夷宗死者七十餘家。

translations.literal: The Grand Historian says: What the world commonly calls military works all discuss Sun Tzu's thirteen chapters and Wu Qi's military strategy. The world has many, so I will not discuss them, but will discuss their actions and achievements.
translations.idiomatic: The Grand Historian says: What the world commonly calls military works all discuss Sun Tzu's thirteen chapters and Wu Qi's military strategy. The world has many, so I will not discuss them, but will discuss their actions and achievements.

translations.literal: He clarified the laws and examined the commands, abolished unnecessary officials, dismissed distant royal clansmen, to nurture and fight with the soldiers. He emphasized strengthening the troops, rejecting the words of the strategists who spoke of alliances and confederacies. Thus he pacified Baiyue in the south; annexed Chen and Cai in the north, drove back the three Jin; attacked Qin in the west. The feudal lords feared Chu's strength. Therefore Chu's nobles all wanted to harm Wu Qi. When King Dao died, the royal clansmen and ministers rebelled and attacked Wu Qi. Wu Qi fled to the king's corpse and lay upon it. Those attacking Qi then shot and stabbed Wu Qi, also hitting King Dao. After King Dao was buried, the crown prince ascended and had the chief minister execute all those who shot Wu Qi and hit the king's corpse. Those executed for shooting Qi and whose clans were exterminated numbered more than seventy families. The Grand Historian says: What the world commonly calls military works all discuss Sun Tzu's thirteen chapters and Wu Qi's military strategy. The world has many, so I will not discuss them, but will discuss their actions and achievements.

sentences.zh: 太史公曰：世俗所稱師旅，皆道孫子十三篇，吳起兵法，世多有，故弗論，論其行事所施設者。

translations.literal: The saying goes: 'Those who can act may not be able to speak, those who can speak may not be able to act.'
translations.idiomatic: The saying goes: 'Those who can act may not be able to speak, those who can speak may not be able to act.'

sentences.zh: 語曰：「能行之者未必能言，能言之者未必能行。」

translations.literal: Sun Tzu clearly strategized against Pang Juan, yet could not early save himself from punishment.
translations.idiomatic: Sun Tzu clearly strategized against Pang Juan, yet could not early save himself from punishment.

sentences.zh: 孫子籌策龐涓明矣，然不能蚤救患於被刑。

translations.literal: Wu Qi explained to Marquis Wu that terrain depends on virtue, yet when he acted in Chu he was harsh and cruel, lacking benevolence, and lost his life.
translations.idiomatic: Wu Qi explained to Marquis Wu that terrain depends on virtue, yet when he acted in Chu he was harsh and cruel, lacking benevolence, and lost his life.

sentences.zh: 吳起說武侯以形勢不如德，然行之於楚，以刻暴少恩亡其軀。

translations.literal: Wu Qi explained to Marquis Wu that terrain depends on virtue, yet when he acted in Chu he was harsh and cruel, lacking benevolence, and lost his life.
translations.idiomatic: Wu Qi explained to Marquis Wu that terrain depends on virtue, yet when he acted in Chu he was harsh and cruel, lacking benevolence, and lost his life.

sentences.zh: 悲夫！

translations.literal: Alas!
translations.idiomatic: Alas!

translations.literal: The saying goes: 'Those who can act may not be able to speak, those who can speak may not be able to act.' Sun Tzu clearly strategized against Pang Juan, yet could not early save himself from punishment. Wu Qi explained to Marquis Wu that terrain depends on virtue, yet when he acted in Chu he was harsh and cruel, lacking benevolence, and lost his life. Alas! Alas!
